text: Maybe I was using it wrong

text: You should really read up on git

elements.text: You should really read up on git

text: Git is a code versioning system where you push your code once you made significant changes. For example adding a new role, fixing a bug or whatever. So even after working 2 years on a codebase you can still see how the code was 2 years ago

elements.text: Git is a code versioning system where you push your code once you made significant changes. For example adding a new role, fixing a bug or whatever. So even after working 2 years on a codebase you can still see how the code was 2 years ago

text: you can still code normally in your IDE you can still push instant the changes you did to the screeps servers, but you simply have a backup and versioning on your code

elements.text: you can still code normally in your IDE you can still push instant the changes you did to the screeps servers, but you simply have a backup and versioning on your code

text: Sometimes I use the browser because I'm not on my own computer, how would I push the changes on to git then?

elements.text: Sometimes I use the browser because I'm not on my own computer, how would I push the changes on to git then?

text: Um, I would never recommend you to code in the browser or in the "IDE" of screeps.

elements.text: Um, I would never recommend you to code in the browser or in the "IDE" of screeps.

text: If you still wanna do that, then you can clone your code from github into the screeps code folder and then make the changes in there and then push the changes back to github or any other platform

elements.text: If you still wanna do that, then you can clone your code from github into the screeps code folder and then make the changes in there and then push the changes back to github or any other platform

text: Not sure if screeps is saving the browsercode in AppData too or if its simply saved in the broswer cache

elements.text: Not sure if screeps is saving the browsercode in AppData too or if its simply saved in the broswer cache

text: Well I have managed ok up till now, thank you for your concern though

elements.text: Well I have managed ok up till now, thank you for your concern though

text: You can create a simlink between where you keep your local copy of your Git repo and where the Steam client keeps the code. If you edit in the browser, as soon as you sync it with the client, you can commit it.

elements.text: You can create a simlink between where you keep your local copy of your Git repo and where the Steam client keeps the code. If you edit in the browser, as soon as you sync it with the client, you can commit it.

text: Hmm ok, may be worth looking at, thanks

elements.text: Hmm ok, may be worth looking at, thanks

text: Git is not only for backups. I just can't code without it anymore. With it and some editor integration, you can see exactly which lines you changed since the last commit, you can easily try something on a branch, then go back to your main code, you can track when something broke, to find out how to fix it, etc.

elements.text: Git is not only for backups. I just can't code without it anymore. With it and some editor integration, you can see exactly which lines you changed since the last commit, you can easily try something on a branch, then go back to your main code, you can track when something broke, to find out how to fix it, etc.

text: <@U01D15GEM2L> has joined the channel

git and grunt is very attractive. As a new player who is learning via screeps, there's definitely a barrier to it's usage. The getting started pages are long and assume previous knowledge or experience. I feel like i should've had this sorted from the start but when all you want to do is start coding and the built in IDE is right there. Now it's a month later, i've got 20+ modules with no file structure and use atom to lint instead of push.  I've committed myself to getting it sorted today...

elements.text: git and grunt is very attractive. As a new player who is learning via screeps, there's definitely a barrier to it's usage. The getting started pages are long and assume previous knowledge or experience. I feel like i should've had this sorted from the start but when all you want to do is start coding and the built in IDE is right there. Now it's a month later, i've got 20+ modules with no file structure and use atom to lint instead of push.  I've committed myself to getting it sorted today...

text: The build is the weak spot of the Javascript ecosystem. Not because the tools aren't there, but because starting a simple project is so darn complicated. You just about have to have specialized knowledge, or rely on someone else's starter kit

text:
I could make the repo private, but I know a lot of ppl are using it to learn.
I removed it from steam workshop and "deleted" the code to stop most basic users without knowledge about how to get it from other sources.
There was already forks available, so the code was out there anyway

elements.text:
I could make the repo private, but I know a lot of ppl are using it to learn.
I removed it from steam workshop and "deleted" the code to stop most basic users without knowledge about how to get it from other sources.
There was already forks available, so the code was out there anyway

text: And I wanted to keep it in npm, because it's one of few bots that can be challenging on a private server. Having four simplebots doesn't exactly prepare you for MMO :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: And I wanted to keep it in npm, because it's one of few bots that can be challenging on a private server. Having four simplebots doesn't exactly prepare you for MMO

text: New versions of KBot will not be released again, but I have been working on a bot called SampleBot to teach some basic principles (both screeps-principles and programming-principles) to new players.

elements.text: New versions of KBot will not be released again, but I have been working on a bot called SampleBot to teach some basic principles (both screeps-principles and programming-principles) to new players.
